data.title: Hang / Slowdown Using Word Based Suggestions in Large Document
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13 Insiders - c615b43be67170e166779c9020a249442c4f36fc

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set:
```
	"editor.wordBasedSuggestions": true,
	"editor.quickSuggestions": {
		"other": true,
		"comments": false,
		"strings": true
	},
```

2. Open this file in VS Code as plain text: [alice.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/991699/alice.txt)


3. Go to the end of line 15 (the one with all the random characters on it) and type the keys `f` + `s` over and over again rapidly

**Bug**
Major slowdown and sometimes the entire process hangs:

![fs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/25929603/51fa1e48-35b6-11e7-9e01-07c5fff03e71.gif)

In the gif, I was typing for about the first 8 seconds or so

data.title: Custom Emmet snippet for Javascript
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.12.1
OS Version: Windows 10 Insider Build 16188.1000

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a **snippets.json** file with the following content
```
{
    "js" : {
        "abbreviations" : {
            "fnrr" : "function (req, res) {\n${cursor}\n}",
            "fnrrn": "function (req, res, next) {\n${cursor}\n}"
        }
    }
}
```
2. Save this file to a local directory, say **D:\DevSettings**
3. Now in the VSCode User settings add the following key-value
```
"emmet.extensionsPath": "D:\\DevSettings\\snippets.json"
```
4. Reload VS Code and open a javascript file.
5. Type **fnrr** and press TAB.

Expected Result: **fnrr** should be replaced with 
```
function (req, res) {

}
```
Actual Result: **Nothing happens!**

data.title: Add Separate Settings For References Code Lens in JavaScript and TypeScript
data.body:
**Bug**
The `typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled` setting currently enables the setting for both js and ts

**fix**
Split this into `typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled` and `javascript.referencesCodeLens.enabled`. Investigate enabling the code lens in TypeScript by default

data.title: Find in selection requires at least two lines to be selected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select a single line of text, e.g. by triple clicking on the line.
2. Alt + Cmd + F to bring up the Find and Replace widget
4. Enter a search term in the Find field -> All occurrences in the document are highlighted
5. Click the "Find in selection" button to toggle it on -> no effect
6. Click "Find in selection" a second time -> the selection changes to the first occurrence of the search term in the document.
7. Click "Find in selection" a third time -> the first occurrence of the search term in the document is matched, whether or not it was on the line you originally selected; no other occurrences are matched.

If you select any more than one line of text, then "Find in selection" works as expected.

data.title: Remove Need for File Extensions in TypeScript Language Definitions
data.body:
Part of #25740

To support TS Server plugins for languages like angular, we will allow extensions to register new langauges for TypeScript to watch. The angular language for example would want ng-html files to also be uploaded to TypeScript for checking

The current language definitions all define both a set of language modes they support and a set of file extensions. The file extension part is unnessiary and may be incorrect depending on how a user sets up their `file.associations` in the workspace.

This change removes the extensions part so that we always make use of the language mode

data.title: Correct LC_ALL.  Resolves #26227
Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000ms - (reason: Cannot connect to the target: Parse Error).
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Pro 64 bits
- NodeJs Version: 6.10.0

Since the last update of vscode (1.12.1), when debugging my typescript/nodejs application (with nodemon), I got the error:

**Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000ms - (reason: Cannot connect to the target: Parse Error).**

The same code/project works very well (without any changes) in the previous version of vscode (1.11.2).

But what is strange, is that the code still working in the background..My functions and other stuff are well executed...but I can't break on any breakpoints and I can't stop/start/pause the debugging process (with Play/Pause/Stop buttons that appears on the top when we start debugging) because buttons for doing that are not visible anymore.  So no break on breakpoints, no debug buttons but code still running in the background.

As I said, I didn't change anything in my code or in my project/debug configuration.

Here is my launch.json config:
```
{
  // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
  // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
  // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch server with Nodemon",
      "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/nodemon",
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "--debug=5858"
      ],
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/src/server.ts",
      "restart": true,
      "port": 5858,
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "console": "integratedTerminal",
      "internalConsoleOptions": "neverOpen",
      "outFiles": ["${workspaceRoot}/build/**/*.js"],
      "sourceMaps": true
    },
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "name": "Attacher au processus",
      "address": "localhost",
      "port": 5858,
      "outFiles": []
    }
  ]
}
```
As I said before, the same code with the same launch.json config works very well with vscode 1.11.2 when debugging with nodemon.

Can you help me please with this issue ?

Thank you for your answers..

data.title: Fix onEnter Rules Detected Language Mode When There is a Selection
data.body:
Fixes #26406

**Bug**
If there is an active selection, the on Enter rules may use the wrong language mode which results in the incorrect `afterEnterText`. See #26406 for an example of this case

**Fix**
Use language mode from the selection and  correctly compute offset when grabbing `afterEnterText`

data.title: Command shortcut in hover text for Find in Selection
data.body:
Ref #8843 

Put command shortcut in hover text for Find in Selection and rename the command for better discoverbility.

data.title: Files stored in SQL 2014 FileTable appear as folders in VSCode Explorer pane
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a FileTable using SQL 2012 or later.  (Script included below to create DB with FileTable)
2. Browse to the folder made available by the new FileTable.
3. Add some text files to this folder.
4. Right-Click the folder in Windows Explorer to "Open with Code"
5. When the list of files appears, note that there is a triangle next to each file.

![e1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1075545/25917360/b93f583c-3595-11e7-9d6d-bca24f4ad24c.png)

6. Note that clicking a file will rotate the left triangle (like when navigating a folder) but will not open the file in the editor.

![e2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1075545/25917436/078b0e00-3596-11e7-8d95-a264a55c596b.png)

Creating a FileTable
---------------------
Below is a TSQL script that can be used to create a database with a file table.  Once created you should be able to browse to \\\\YOURSERVER\MSSQLSERVER\MyDbDir\MyDataFile
Script adapted from http://www.databasejournal.com/features/mssql/filetable-in-sql-server-2012.html


USE [master]
GO
 
/****** Object:  Database [MyDB]    Script Date: 5/23/2012 4:25:56 PM ******/
CREATE DATABASE [MyDB]
 CONTAINMENT = NONE
 ON  PRIMARY 
( NAME = N'MyDB_Data', FILENAME = N'D:\SQL Server\Data\MyDB_Data.mdf' , SIZE = 5000KB , MAXSIZE = UNLIMITED, FILEGROWTH = 1024KB ), 
 FILEGROUP [MyFilestreamFG] CONTAINS FILESTREAM  DEFAULT 
( NAME = N'MyFileStreamData', FILENAME = N'D:\Test\Data' , MAXSIZE = UNLIMITED)
 LOG ON 
( NAME = N'MyDB_Log', FILENAME = N'D:\SQL Server\Data\MyDB_log.ldf' , SIZE = 1024KB , MAXSIZE = 2048GB , FILEGROWTH = 10%)
GO
 
ALTER DATABASE [MyDB] SET COMPATIBILITY_LEVEL = 120
GO

ALTER DATABASE [MyDB] SET FILESTREAM ( NON_TRANSACTED_ACCESS = FULL, DIRECTORY_NAME = N'MyDbDir' )
 
IF (1 = FULLTEXTSERVICEPROPERTY('IsFullTextInstalled'))
begin
EXEC [MyDB].[dbo].[sp_fulltext_database] @action = 'enable'
end
GO

Use MyDB
go

CREATE TABLE MyDataFiles AS FileTable
WITH
(
    FileTable_Directory = 'MyDataFiles',
    FileTable_Collate_Filename = database_default
);
GO

data.title: Integrated Terminal: Move Cursor by Clicking

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm using macOS for developing all the stuff.
In its `Terminal.app` it is possible to move the cursor in the current line by holding the `Option` key and left-click at the desired position. I recorded this behaviour:

![](http://dev.whotheheck.de/s/terminal.gif)

It's described by [MacKungFu](http://www.mackungfu.org/3-lesser-known-terminal-tricks):

> Move the cursor by clicking: If you’re editing a file in nano, emacs or vim you can hold down Option (Alt) then click anywhere in the file to move the cursor there. Yes, I know — this shouldn’t work. But it does! It works at the command line too — you can jump to anywhere in the line you’re currently typing by holding down Option and clicking there.

Because @Tyriar confirmed that there is no such feature in the integrated terminal and no corresponding feature request, I wanna request for this feature hereby. 

Thanks a lot.

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Scroll (I'm using magic touch pad, but same happens with regular touch pad on mac)

When I first found out about vs code, this issue was there. A patch was released that fixed the laggy scrolling issues. Seems to have come back now. It's so bad I can't even scan through a 200 line class and find methods.

data.title: Request: non-sticky diff editor window
data.body:
I noticed VS Code User Voice portal has been deprecated and redirects here, so:

### Scenario:

* setup VS Code so to show differences in files side by side
* make some changes to a versioned project
* go to Source Control pane
* start clicking on several changed files

### Actual behavior:

Any clicked files opens a new diff editor window, which stay open. After clicking through some changed file, there's a whole lot of opened diff windows hanging around.

### Desired behavior:

Have a setting available in VS Code deciding whether diff editor windows should remain open (*sticky*) or not. When option is "sticky", everything stays the same as now. When option is "not sticky", clicking through different changed files should be the same as clicking through files in explorer pane: only the last clicked diff should be visibile as an editor.

Thanks!

data.title: Structurally typed identifiers' tooltips should show the type definition, not just `enum MyEnum` or `interface MyInterface`
data.body:
Especially for structurally-typed enums and interfaces, it would be helpful if tooltips showed (at least the initial text of) the type definition - similar to how it shows function signatures for function identifiers:

![fd78dc73-59f6-4794-ae3d-1f4dd1075e5f](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17498172/25905699/b5c7fe0e-3570-11e7-8125-b714fd3298d1.gif)

Seeing that the identifier is an interface or an enum is minimally helpful, but getting a reminder of this type's definition is what I'm really after when I ask.

data.title: VSCode Typescript imported identifier tooltips do not show helpful type information
data.body:
VSCode 1.12.1 with Typescript 2.3.2

See the two files in the screenshot are even from the same src project, where _helper.ts_ imports _rules.ts_.  Here I might be attempting to confirm that I did the write syntax (instead of `import * as blah from 'rules.ts` or some other tricky nuance that can come up (though not necessarily in this exact example).  Instead of showing what type the imported name has, it just says `import testFunction` which is completely useless here, since that's obvious from the text.

![0f2be476-8026-4a03-9a30-d359dd6efb0b](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17498172/25904968/c4dceeec-356e-11e7-9a33-8399c8acea51.gif)

Upon usage of `testFunction()`, the tooltip is helpful, but NOT for all types, such as an `enum`.  At the site of usage of the imported `triggerModes`, it just shows that it is an import:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17498172/25905312/b40f5d06-356f-11e7-8ae9-feb631acbba6.png)
